As the temperature drops, the action potential duration in myocardial cells increases, leading to prolonged repolarization and a prolonged QT interval. This can increase the risk of arrhythmias. AV block: Atrioventricular (AV) block is also commonly seen in hypothermia, especially in its severe forms. Hypothermic patients may develop first-degree AV block (prolonged PR interval), second-degree AV block, or even third-degree AV block. The degree of AV block can vary depending on the severity of the hypothermia and the extent of electrical conduction slowing. Incorrect Options: A. Bradycardia Bradycardia is indeed observed in this patient due to the hypothermic state. This option is correct but incomplete on its own. Since the question asks for all the ECG findings in hypothermia, the correct answer includes additional features beyond bradycardia. B. QT prolongation While QT prolongation is a hallmark ECG finding in hypothermia, it is not the only finding in this patient. Bradycardia and AV block are also common. The best answer is D, which includes all the features commonly seen in hypothermia. C. AV block AV block can certainly occur in hypothermia, but it is not the only abnormality present. The presence of bradycardia and QT prolongation further support D as the correct answer. Therefore, selecting AV block alone would ignore other important ECG findings in this patient.

questions.text: A 60 year old male comes for his cardiac evaluation.He wants to eliminate the possibility of ischemic heart disease due to his family history.He is a smoker,non-alcoholic and is going through a rough business.He is a known case of aortic stenosis due to bicuspid aortic valve.He also gives h/o suggestive of intermittent claudication.Resting ECG is normal.You are planning for tread mill test. All the following are absolute contraindications for Tread mill test except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) For CI of TMT - post MI it is within 2 days of MI.For severe AS it is symptomatic severe AS.Peripheral vascular is not an absolute CI.

questions.text: A 35 year old male chronic smoker was being evaluated for presence of coronary artery disease. There is no past history of hypertension, dyslipidemia and diabetes. His father died at young age due to ischemic heart disease. You get a resting ECG done which is normal. You plan for tread mill test to diagnose CAD. While doing TMT which of the following is not an indication to stop tread mill exercise test
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Increase in systolic BP > 20 mmHg. During a treadmill exercise test (TMT), blood pressure response is closely monitored. A normal physiological response to exercise is an increase in systolic blood pressure (SBP), often rising by about 20-30 mmHg with moderate to intense exertion. Therefore, an increase in systolic BP by > 20 mmHg is not a reason to stop the test, as this is within the expected range of response during exercise. It is an appropriate physiological reaction and is usually not an indicator of distress or a problem. If BP rises dramatically beyond this (such as more than 250 mmHg systolic), it would be a concern and may require stopping, but a modest increase of >20 mmHg alone is not an indication for test cessation. Incorrect Options: B. Development of cyanosis Cyanosis is a clear indication of insufficient oxygenation and suggests that the body is not receiving adequate oxygen supply, potentially due to severe coronary artery disease or respiratory compromise. This warrants immediate cessation of the test to prevent harm and further compromise the patient's health. C. Patient request to stop If the patient expresses a desire to stop the test, this is always a valid and critical reason to stop the treadmill test immediately. The patient's well-being, comfort, and safety are paramount, and respecting their request to stop ensures that the test is not pushed beyond their tolerance or safety limits. D. ST elevation > 1mm The presence of ST elevation greater than 1mm during exercise testing could indicate a myocardial infarction (MI) or acute ischemia, making it a strong indication to stop the test immediately. This is a concerning finding and requires prompt medical evaluation and intervention.
